Prevent the Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand: If I had the power to change one historical event, I would go back in time to prevent the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914. This event was the spark that ignited World War I, one of the deadliest conflicts in human history. By preventing his assassination, I could potentially prevent the war and all its attendant horrors, including the loss of millions of lives, widespread destruction, and a global economic collapse.

Avoid the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD: I would go back in time to prevent the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD, which destroyed the ancient Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum. This event caused the deaths of thousands of people and buried their cities under a thick layer of ash and pumice. By preventing the eruption, I could save countless lives and preserve these ancient cities, which offer a unique glimpse into the daily life of the ancient Romans.

Prevent the Sinking of the Titanic: I would go back in time to prevent the sinking of the Titanic in 1912. This tragic event resulted in the deaths of over 1,500 people and had a profound impact on maritime safety regulations. By preventing the sinking, I could save countless lives and prevent a tragedy that continues to captivate the public imagination to this day.

Stop the Invention of the Internet: I would go back in time to prevent the invention of the internet. While the internet has revolutionized the way we communicate and access information, it has also had a profound impact on our attention spans, social interactions, and mental health. By preventing its invention, I could slow the pace of technological progress and give people more time to focus on face-to-face interactions and other meaningful pursuits.
